title: USF shooting triggers debate on campus carry bill
text:
USF shooting triggers debate on campus carry bill Tammie Fields, WTSP 4:06 p.m. EDT October 12, 2015 USF player's arrest triggers debate on packing heat on campus Benjamin Knox was arrested by USF police for firing a weapon into the exterior of a campus dormitory. (Photo: Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office and USF Athletics) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Tampa, Florida -- Many University of South Florida students are still reeling from the news that a USF football player is accused of firing shots at a residence hall where students were studying and sleeping early Sunday morning. 
The incident left huge gaping holes in the plaster of a residence hall triggering a new debate over a current bill to allow guns on campus. 
USF police swarmed the Crescent Hill parking garage on Holly Drive after the gunshots were reported around 4 a.m. They found shell casings and eventually a parked vehicle with an open gun case, and an empty of ammunition sitting next to the car. 
Investigators say the owner of the vehicle is 21-year-old Benjamin Knox from DeLand, a redshirt freshman offensive lineman for the football team. 
Assistant Chief Chris Daniel says he's opposed to legislation to allow people to pack heat on campus. 
"To me this is a perfect example as to why they should not be on campus. Had the first officer who showed up - who was tactically trained - saw two people with guns we don't know who the good guy is and who the bad guy is and that increases the likelihood of some innocent person getting hurt." 
Daniel, a father of 4 who has a daughter who attended FSU, understands parents concerns. He says he wants them to know their children are safe at USF. 
Florida Rep. Greg Stuebe, R-Sarasota, proposed the controversial bill and believes students would be safer though if those with a concealed carry permit were allowed to carry a gun on Florida's college campuses. Florida bill to allow guns on campuses moves forward 
While several USF students said they were opposed to having guns on campus, one student said he liked the idea of packing heat. Chase Brown says, "I do outside of school - so I don't see why I wouldn't when I come to school." 
But two USF students from Columbia offer a completely different perspective saying guns aren't allowed on campuses in their homeland and they say they don't have the violence we have on college campuses here. 
When asked if they would like to have the option to protect themselves here in the U.S., since we have had several mass shootings on college campuses, one of them said, "I will never carry a gun. No way." 
Meanwhile, Knox didn't speak during his court appearance Monday morning on charges of Possession or Discharge of a Firearm on Campus, and Shooting into an Occupied Dwelling. 
Benjamin Knox makes his first appearance in court on Oct. 12. (Photo: WTSP) 
His family attended the hearing and the judge appointed a public defender to his case. Knox has been suspended from the football team and remains in jail after the set his bond at $32,500. If he is released, he is not allowed to possess a firearm or go on any USF property. 
USF Athletics Department made a statement about the incident: 
USF Athletics is aware of an incident involving student-athlete Benjamin Knox that occurred early Sunday morning. The student-athlete in question has been immediately suspended from all team activities. We are in the process of gathering more information on the matter and are working with the proper authorities. This type of behavior is not consistent with the values of our institution and will not be tolerated. Read or Share this story: http://on.wtsp.com/1RD4eqK TOP VIDEOS
